etymologies: late 18th century: from French carbone, from Latin carbo, carbon- ‘coal, charcoal’

notes.text: Compounds of carbon (organic compounds) form the physical basis of all living organisms. Carbon atoms are able to link with each other and with other atoms to form chains and rings, and an infinite variety of carbon compounds exist

definitions: the chemical element of atomic number 6, a nonmetal which has two main forms (diamond and graphite) and which also occurs in impure form in charcoal, soot, and coal.

examples.text: a bike with a carbon frame

definitions: a rod of carbon in an arc lamp.
shortDefinitions: rod of carbon in arc lamp

definitions: a piece of carbon paper or a carbon copy.
shortDefinitions: piece of carbon paper or carbon copy

definitions: carbon dioxide or other gaseous carbon compounds released into the atmosphere, associated with climate change

examples.text: the level of carbon in the atmosphere has been consistently rising
fossil fuel consumption and carbon emissions continued to rise

shortDefinitions: carbon dioxide or other gaseous carbon compounds released into atmosphere
